titleStmt.title: NbTaV-(Ti,W) refractory high-entropy alloys: Experiments and modeling

analytic.title: NbTaV-(Ti,W) refractory high-entropy alloys: Experiments and modeling

biblStruct.note: Received 16 February 2016 Received in revised form 24 July 2016 Accepted 25 July 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High-entropy alloys Refractory Single-phase Design Ductile

div.p: This study reports the design and development of ductile and strong refractory single-phase high-entropy alloys (HEAs) for high temperature applications, based on NbTaV with addition of Ti and W. Assisted by CALPHAD modeling, a single body-centered cubic solid solution phase was experimentally confirmed in the as-cast ingots using X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy. The observed elemental segregation in each alloy qualitatively agrees with CALPHAD prediction. The Vickers microhardnesses (and yield strengths) of the alloys are about 3 (and 3.5-4.4) times that those estimated from the rule of mixture. While NbTaTiVW shows an impressive yield strength of 1420 MPa with fracture strain of 20%, NbTaTiV exhibits exceptional compressive ductility at room temperature.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Structural engineering materials with high strength, acceptable ductility, and good thermal stability are highly desirable for critical applications [1,2]. Conventional alloys have one principal element as the matrix, with minor modifications achieved by adding relatively small amounts of other alloying elements. This strategy typically optimizes a set of physical or mechanical properties while retaining the base characteristic properties of the main alloying matrix element. Over the past decade, a new alloy design and development philosophy-high-entropy alloys (HEAs), or multi-principle-element alloys (MPEAs)-has attracted significant attention [3,4]. Such alloys generally consist of four, or more elements with equimolar or nearequimolar ratios that form face-centered cubic (FCC) [4], bodycentered cubic (BCC) [5], or hexagonal close-packed (HCP) phases [6,7]. A shared rationale is to maximize the configurational entropy by increasing the number of the principal components, thereby, in theory, continuing to improve the thermal stability of disordered solid-solution phases against intermetallics, especially at elevated temperatures. A number of HEAs have showed a variety of favorable, and sometimes unusual properties such as high strength, high ductility, high fracture toughness at low temperatures, and thermal stability. (For recent comprehensive reviews on HEAs, the reader is referred to Refs. [8,9]).

Traditional refractory metals and alloys hold great potential in high temperature applications beyond the capability of the stateof-the-art Ni-based superalloys, primarily due to their extremely high melting points, but they also suffer from low ductility at low temperatures and their oxidation resistance is poor [10]. Recent development on refractory HEAs suggests that they may exhibit outstanding strength [11] and exceptional oxidation resistance [12]. The main objective of the present work is to explore the design potential of single-phase refractory HEAs, namely, NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW. These HEAs possess the BCC structure, resulting in alloys that are ductile and strong. The base alloy NbTaV was chosen since elements Nb, Ta, and V, separately, show excellent ductility at room temperature [13].

div.head: Computational methodologies and experimental procedures
div.p: The CALPHAD calculations were performed using the TCNI7 thermodynamic database supplied by ThermoCalc™ [14]. The Contents lists available at ScienceDirect journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/msea database covers the complete binaries pertaining to nine refractory metals although it was initially developed for Ni-based superalloys. Previous CALPHAD modeling using this database demonstrated good agreement with experimental observations for various refractory BCC HEAs [15][16][17], but future development including descriptions for all possible ternary alloys in their complete composition ranges will definitely enhance the reliability of the database in the applications for HEAs. For guidance on CAL-PHAD modeling of HEAs, the reader is referred to recent publications [18][19][20][21].

Alloy ingots with nominal compositions of NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW (compositions in at.%) were synthesized by vacuum arc melting of the equimolar pure metals (weight percentage purity Z99.9%) in a Ti-gettered, high-purity argon atmosphere. Arc melting of the alloys was conducted on a water-cooled copper hearth crucible. To achieve as homogeneous distribution of elements as possible in the alloys using this melting technique, the ingots were remelted at least seven times, flipping them over between each melt. The resulting crystal structures developed in the solidified ingots were identified using X-ray diffraction. Cu Kα radiation was used through the 2θ range between 20°and 80°. The morphologies and microstructures of the as-cast alloys were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) capability. Vickers microhardness was used to determine the alloy hardness. An indent was placed on the polished cross-section surface, using a 136°Vickers diamond pyramid under 1 kg load, applied for 15 s. Cylindrical specimens for compression testing were electric-discharged machined from the cast ingots. The samples were 3 mm in diameter and 6 mm in height giving an aspect ratio of 1:2. The two end surfaces of the cylindrical compression specimen were carefully polished to obtain mirror-like surfaces as well as to insure planar and parallel sided surfaces. A MTS 809 universal testing machine was used to perform the compression tests at room temperature using a nominal strain rate of 5 Â 10 À 4 s À 1 .

div.head: CALPHAD modeling
div.p: The predicted equilibrium phase mole fraction versus temperature plots for these alloys are shown in Fig. 1 decomposition temperature (T dec ) of the BCC phase are listed in Table 1. HEA NbTaVW shows the greatest thermal stability since it possesses the highest T liq and T sol , as well as the lowest T dec , followed by NbTaTiVW and then NbTaTiV. The non-equilibrium solidification simulation was accomplished using the Scheil-Gulliver model [22,23], which assumes equilibrium mixing in the liquid and no diffusion in the solid. The simulations predict formation of a single BCC solid solution during the entire non-equilibrium solidification for the three alloys. An example is shown in Fig. 2 for HEA NbTaTiVW. The real solidification path will lie somewhere between equilibrium and Scheil model (Fig. 2(a)). The simulation also predicts likely segregation tendency due to constitutional cooling. As the temperature decreases during solidification, the liquid is gradually depleted in W followed by Ta. Alternatively, it is steadily enriched in Ti followed by V (Fig. 2(b)). In contrast, the BCC phase is predicted to be rich in W and Ta in the dendrites that form at earlier stages of solidification. At latter stages of solidification, the BCC phase is enriched Table 1 Predicted liquidus, solidus, and decomposition temperatures and mixing thermodynamic properties using TCNI7 database.

div.head: Alloys
div.p: T liq (K) in Ti and V in interdendritic regions (Fig. 2(c)).
div.formula: T sol (K) T dec (K) ∆H mix liq (kJ/mol) ∆H mix bcc (kJ/mol) ∆S mix liq (J K À 1 mol À 1 ) ∆S mix bcc (J K À 1 mol À 1 ) NbTaTiV 2411 2177 709 À 0.1 þ 3.

div.head: Crystal structure
div.p: X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-cast samples are shown in Fig. 3. The XRD peaks of the alloys are indexed as single phase BCC. The lattice parameters were determined to be 3.2193 Å, 3.2186 Å, and 3.2244 Å, respectively, for NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW (see Table 2). These values agree very well with those estimated from the rule of mixture (ROM) [24]:
div.formula: ∑ = ( ) = a c a , 1 mix i 1 n i i
div.p: where c i and a i are the atomic fraction and the lattice parameter of the i th element, respectively, and n is the number of alloy com- ponents. The lattice parameters of pure elements, taken from Ref.
[13], are given in Table 2.

div.head: Microstructure and chemical compositions
div.p: Backscattered-electron SEM images of the investigated alloys are presented in Fig. 4. The dendritic microstructure is clearly seen in these alloys, which is typical of as-cast ingots. The dendrite arms appear to be "brighter" (in terms of SEM contrast) than the interdendritic regions. This qualitatively implies that the dendrite arms may be enriched in elements with more electrons (i.e., in other words, those heavy metals with high melting points in this case) than the interdendritic regions. Elemental segregation was further examined in NbTaTiVW using the EDS mapping on a small region (see Fig. 5 for details). For this example, W and Ta were mostly observed in the dendrite arm regions, while Nb, Ti, and V enrichments were observed in the interdendritic regions. The EDS results qualitatively agree with the simulated composition profile generated for non-equilibrium solidification using CALPHAD.

The estimated bulk composition of the alloys ( C aver ), the aver- age composition of the dendritic arms ( C dr ), and the average composition of the interdendritic regions ( C idr ) are listed in Ta- ble 3. The measured C aver deviates from the nominal concentration as a result of evaporation losses for each element during the melting process. In agreement with the qualitative analysis of the backscattered electron imaging (BEI) SEM images, the distribution of the elements in the as-cast alloys is inhomogeneous. Heavier metals with higher melting points are enriched in the dendrite arms, e.g., Ta and Nb for the NbTaTiV alloy; W and Ta for the NbTaVW and NbTaTiVW alloys. Conversely, lighter elements with lower melting points are enriched in the interdendritic regions.

div.head: Compressive properties and hardness
div.p: The true stress-strain (σ ε -) curves at room temperature (298 K) for the HEAs in this study are depicted in Fig. 6. The yield strength (i.e., σ 0.2 is defined as the stress at ε ¼0.2%.) for each HEA was determined and these values are listed in Table 2. The plastic fracture strains are 12% and 20% for the alloys NbTaVW and NbTaTiVW, respectively. Work hardening was observed in each alloy. Of particular note was HEA NbTaTiV, which did not fracture at the test compressive strain limit of 50%. An approximate workhardening exponent, N, can be estimated using the Holloman equation:

where σ is the stress, k is the strengthening coefficient, and ε is the plastic strain [25]. The values of N were determined to be 0.12, 0.07, and 0.1 for alloys NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW, respectively. Large N value often indicates more uniform plasticity. The values of k were determined to be 1468, 2160, and 1992 for the alloys NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW, respectively. The average Vickers microhardness values ( H v ) of the pure elements [13] and the alloys studied at ambient testing conditions are listed in Table 2.

div.head: Phase formation
div.p: Several empirical parameters have been proposed to predict phase formation and structural stability in HEAs [26][27][28][29]. According to the classic Hume-Rothery rules, atomic size difference ( δ), valence electron concentration ( VEC ), and electronegativity dif- ference impact the formation of solid solutions. Besides these parameters, entropy and enthalpy of mixing (∆H mix ) are the most critical phase formation factors for HEAs. The δ and ∆H mix can be expressed as:

div.head: Table 2
div.p: The crystal lattice parameter (a), atomic radius (r), melting temperature (T m ), Vickers hardness (H v ), and yield strength (σ 0.2 ) in pure metals [13] are given. The calculated and experimental data for NbTaV-(Ti,W) HEAs are listed here.

div.head: Metal
div.formula: ∑ δ= ( ̅ ) ( ) = 100% c 1-r /r , 3 i 1 n i i 2 ∑ ∆ = ω ( ) = = ̸ H 4 c c , 4 mix i 1,j i n ij i j
div.p: where c i (r i ) is the atomic fraction (the Goldschmidt atomic radius [13]) of the i th component, and ω ij is the enthalpy of mixing be- tween i th and j th elements [30], which is based on the Miedema model [31]. The ∆H mix reflects the tendency of forming stable in- termetallic compounds while the δ characterizes the atomic size mismatch. Such an approach addresses the local elastic strain and the system topological instability [32]. Zhang et al. [26], for example, suggested that the criteria for forming random solid solutions alloys solidified from the melt were À15 o ∆H mix o5 kJ/mol and δ o5%.

Based on the concept of entropy-enthalpy competition, the Ω-parameter was proposed to be beneficial: n i m i is the calculated average melting temperature. The ∆S mix of HEAs is the ideal configurational entropy (∆S mix conf ) in the solid/liquid state and is expressed as:
div.formula: ∑ ∆ = ( ) = S -R clnc, 6 mix conf i 1 n i i
div.p: where R is the gas constant (8.314 J k À 1 mol À 1 ). From available data, it was concluded that only solid solution phases were formed in many HEAs for Ω≥1.1 and δ≤ 6.6%. For the current alloys, the relationship of Ω versus ( δ versus ∆H mix ) is shown in Fig. 7. The data of other alloys are taken from Ref. [26].

In addition, Guo et al. [28] proposed that the FCC solid solution is stabilized for VEC Z8, and in the particular case of BCC solution, it is stabilized for VEC o6.87. Coexistence of FCC and BCC phases is observed at VEC values between 6.87 and 8. The VEC for multi- component alloys can be defined as:
div.formula: ∑ = ( ) = VEC c VEC , 7 i n i i 1
div.p: where VEC i is the VEC of the i th element. The calculated VEC values for NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW HEAs are 4.74, 5.21, and 5.02, respectively, each of which is much lower than the proposed threshold value of 6.87.

div.head: Thermodynamic properties analyses
div.p: The present research demonstrates that these empirical parameters are useful in predicting the phases that form during solidification. However, it should be noted that the Ω-parameter is calculated using the ideal configurational ∆S mix and ∆H mix for li- quid phase as well as an estimated melting point. Consequently, the Ω-parameter may vary substantially if the thermodynamic properties of the solid phase and the liquidus temperature are used, as pointed out by Gao et al. [16]. Accordingly, the thermodynamic properties of the Nb-Ta-Ti-V-W system were further studied using CALPHAD.

The calculated enthalpies of mixing and entropies of mixing for both BCC and liquid phases (i.e., ∆H mix liq , ∆H mix bcc , ∆S mix liq , and ∆S mix bcc ) are listed in the Table 1. NbTaTiV shows nearly zero ∆H mix liq and positive ∆H mix bcc , and the entropies of mixing for both liquid and BCC phases equal the ideal configurational entropy. In contrast, NbTaTiW and NbTaTiVW show apparent negative deviation from the ideal configurational entropy, which may be due to chemical ordering, chemical separation, and/or lattice phonon vibration. The enthalpies of mixing are negative for both liquid and BCC phases for NbTaTiW and NbTaTiVW. Although the entropies of mixing are fairly close between liquid and BCC phases, there are noticeable differences in the enthalpies of mixing between liquid and BCC phases for each alloy. This is not surprising as a prior study by Gao et al. [16] also showed apparent difference between ∆H mix liq and ∆H mix bcc for sixteen refractory BCC HEAs. In that study [16], both the sign and absolute values of ∆H mix bcc were not necessarily in accord with ∆H mix liq : For example, nine alloys exhibited opposite sign, while seven alloys show significant difference in their absolute values.

To analyze the compositional dependence of the thermodynamic properties, the mixing behaviors in entropy, enthalpy, and Gibbs energy for the BCC phase for four pseudo-binaries of NbTaV-Ti, NbTaV-W, NbTaVW-Ti, and NbTaTiV-W at 1273 K were calculated. These results are shown in Fig. 8. The ∆S mix bcc for NbTaV-W, NbTaVW-Ti, and NbTaTiV-W pseudo-binaries lie well below their ideal mixing entropies, and thus they exhibit negative excess

div.head: Table 3
div.p: The estimated bulk composition (C aver ), the average composition of dendrite arms ( C dr ), the average composition of interdendrite regions( C idr ), and the partition coefficient ( = K C /C dr idr ) for NbTaV-(Ti,W) HEAs.

div.head: Microsegregation
div.p: The microsegregation of the elemental constituents demonstrates non-equilibrium solidification of the HEAs between the liquidus and solidus temperatures. Therefore, homogeneous distribution of the alloying elements in the growing solid phases is kinetically restricted [5]. The level of the element segregation is triggered by the different solidification temperatures associated with each element in the alloy system. The partition coefficient, = K C /C dr idr [33], is commonly used to quantitatively evaluate the microsegregation of the alloying elements. The K value of an alloying element, which reflects the correlation of the excess/deficiency of the concentration in the dendrite arms, is often associated with its melting temperature ( T m ). The elements with high melting temperature in the alloy will usually solidify first in the dendrite arms, constraining those elements with lower melting temperature to solidify later in the solidification process in the interdendritic regions. The correlation between K and temperature can be described as:
0.0013 T where e is the natural base, and
div.formula: ( ) ∆ = - T T T i m i m mix .
div.p: Here, ( )
is the melting temperature of the i th element, and T m mix is the calculated average melting temperature of the alloy.

The relationship between the K value of the i th element (Ti, V, Nb, Ta, or W) in the present alloys and the temperature difference (see Fig. 9) shows that the segregation of the i th element obeys a power-law distribution with ∆T i , which was also observed in other refractory HEAs [34]. For the elements with ΔT i 4 0, the partition coefficient is K41; for the elements with ΔT i o 0, the partition coefficient is Ko1. On the other hand, the predicted microsegregation of the NbTaTiVW alloy using the Scheil model via CALPHAD simulations are in qualitative agreement with experimental observation (see Fig. 2), and this indicates the usefulness of CALPHAD modeling for alloy design and solidification prediction. More realistic solidification of HEAs will involve both mobility and thermodynamic databases [20].

div.head: Room-temperature yield strength and hardness
div.p: In general, materials properties cannot be estimated using the ROM because they are sensitive to alloying elements and their concentrations. The ROM can be expressed as follow:
div.formula: ∑ = ( ) = p cp, 9 i 1 n i i
div.p: where c i and p i are the atomic fraction and mechanical property of the i th constituent element, respectively. The calculated average values of σ 0.2 mix and H v mix are tabulated in Table 2, which are much smaller than the measured values. The results suggest that the mechanical properties of the three alloys disobey the simple ROM, and aspects of solid solution strengthening (SSS) may play a more dominant role than expected. Similar observations have been reported in other single-phase HEAs. The measured Vickers hardness for CoCrFeNi [35], MoNbTaV [36], MoNbTaW [5], MoNbTaVW [5], HfNbTaTiZr [37], MoNbTaTiVW [38], HfNbTaTiVZr [15], and CrMoNbTaVW [17] are 1.58, 4.5, 2.49, 3.37, 3.28, 3.40, 5.09, and 4.69 times the average values obtained from the ROM, respectively. However, little SSS is observed in the HCP GdHoLaTbY alloy [39] which behaves as an ideal solid solution because of the combination of extremely low Δχ (0.05) and zero ΔH mix value, the lattice distortion is minimal, and thus, the solid solution strengthening is negligible.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In summary, three refractory HEAs, NbTaTiV, NbTaVW, and NbTaTiVW, were designed by CALPHAD modeling and synthesized by vacuum arc melting. A single BCC solid solution phase was observed in the as-cast alloys using a combination of XRD and SEM analyses. The following conclusions were reached:

1) While NbTaTiV is very ductile and does not fracture up to 50% strain, NbTaTiVW has a yield strength of 1420 MPa with a fracture plastic strain of 20%. 2) The Vickers microhardness values (and the yield strengths) of the HEAs are about 3 (and 3.5-4.4) times that those estimated from the rule of mixture, suggesting contribution from matrix solid solution strengthening.

3) The microsegregation behavior of the elements is closely related to their melting points, and the experimental results are consistent with CALPHAD prediction. 4) The entropies of mixing for both liquid and BCC phases for HEA NbTaTiV are predicted to be ideal. Conversely, HEAs NbTaVW and NbTaTiVW show negative departure from ideal.
